title: Can creditors take my SS and pension from my bank account once it posts?
question: This applies to California law.
answers: I urge you to seek assistance from a bankruptcy attorney in your area who can analyze your situation and can provide advice on the best way to proceed. Find attorney from this site or someone in your area that has a focus in bankruptcy law. You have a lot of questions that need discussion so you can fully understand your options.

The bankruptcy trustee may not necessarily sue your daughter. There are a few factors that go into that and just because you helped her with certain living expenses does not automatically means you are at fault or that she is exposed to a risk of a trustee lawsuit. On this, I really suggest you talk to a bankruptcy lawyer and schedule a consultation.

For your SS and pension question, if a creditor obtains a judgment against you they can levy your bank account. Once that happens it is up to you to tell the Court through court papers that the levied funds in the bank account are protected SS and pension income. There are strict deadlines on submitting those papers once the levy happens. On this I also suggest you speak with a bankruptcy attorney so you know what to expect and how to address it now before a levy happens.

I hope this is helpful.

As Mr. Firth mentioned above - get a bankruptcy consultation with a seasoned bankruptcy attorney. Moreover, as mentioned by Ms. Espada there is a process that the creditor must employ before your deposits become at-risk.

Finally, I would caution you to reconsider receiving your pension and SSI, and then transferring into your daughter's account. This can result in other unintended consequences.

In short - don't self-evaluate, don't act without an action plan . . . Seek counsel and develop a game plan of action.

In order for creditors to take money from a debtor's bank account, it must do all of the following: (1) file a lawsuit against debtor; (2) get judgment against debtor; (3) get a writ of execution to enforce the judgment; (4) serve Notice of Levy on debtor's bank. If none of those things have happened yet, your income is not currently at risk of being taken by creditors.

Even if you are sued, and lose the case, you can claim all of your Social Security income as "exempt" (which means that the Social Security funds will not be accessible to the creditor). Pension money that goes into your bank accounts may be subject to a levy, but you can claim an exemption for any money that is needed for support of yourself and your family.

Providing regular financial support to family members who are unable to support themselves is not "fraudulent transfer" of assets. Those funds cannot be recovered by creditors. If you continue to be worried about defaulting on credit card debts, contact a bankruptcy attorney or debt collection defense attorney in your area. Most provide free consultations.
My advice is to see an experienced bankruptcy attorney because the advice you have been given doesn't add up to me. Most offer free initial consultations.
